articles.title: What Is a Shader?
Show HN: Building a no-code browser automation system for OSINT
articles.description:
I have been working on a browser automation system for OSINT analysts. I took this up because the tools that exist today have a few problems:

1. They require a little more precise notions of what needs to be done by the system (like, go here, click here, then do this, then do that etc.)

2. To perform complex tasks, the few tools that exist, they need some knowledge of the system itself (like telling it to call a specific function or a class etc.)

My goal with this project (I call it `pyba`) was to abstract everything from the user's side. I have two "exploratory" modes built into it, these are for Depth First Search (wherein, it will pick one train of thought, and execute that in full, then revert), or Breadth First Search (where it executes multiple tangential plans in parallel).

All an analyst has to do is type out in words, everything they already know and can share, and what all they'd like to find out more. To ensure that there are no roadblocks in this journey, I also have hardcoded logins, which read your credentials from the environment and log you in to websites like gmail, facebook and instagram (so your credentials never go to the LLM).

And of course, you can use it for normal stuff as well (like tell it to scroll reels for you if you want)!

Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46023610

Points: 1

Show HN: Promptsref â€“ Curated Midjourney SREF library with full prompts
articles.description:
I'm a product manager-turned-solo dev, and I'm building Promptsref, a curated Midjourney SREF library with full prompts, images and examples.

Promptsref helps you: Quickly discover good SREF styles without trawling X/Discord/paid PDFs Reuse full prompts + SREF to reliably reproduce a style Explore by â€œvibeâ€ (comic, cyberpunk, film still, etc.) instead of guessing keywords

Why I built itï¼š I started Promptsref after getting frustrated with Midjourney. As a beginner I kept seeing amazing styles, but they were: 1. buried in long X threads or Discord chats 2. shared as just a code or a partial prompt 3. almost impossible to reliably reproduce later I wanted a place where I could save only the styles that consistently look good, with the exact prompt + SREF + example images in one place. That slowly turned into this project.

How it worksï¼š For each SREF on Promptsref I store: the SREF code, the full prompt I used, example images (and sometimes video styles) You can browse by tags and â€œstyle vibeâ€, copy a code you like, paste the full prompt into Midjourney, and usually get a similar result in a few generations. I update the library based on the styles I use in my own work and what the small community around the site seems to like.

Tech details: Frontend: Next.js, deployed on Vercel Backend: Supabase/Postgres to store SREFs, prompts, metadata and favorites

Things Iâ€™ve learned / had to work around: Designing search for non-technical creatives is harder than just â€œadd a search boxâ€ Keeping SREFs useful when Midjourney updates models requires pruning and re-curating People care a lot about consistency (series, brands, comics), not just one-off pretty images

What Iâ€™d love feedback on: If you use Midjourney, Iâ€™d really appreciate feedback on: Is the search / navigation understandable? What information about a style do you wish you saw first? Is there a better way to show series / collections of styles? Any obvious technical improvements youâ€™d make to the stack or data model?

Link: https://promptsref.com

Thanks for reading, and Iâ€™m happy to answer any questions about the implementation, data model, or the SREF curation process.

Points: 1

articles.title: Show HN: I built a simple, fast, privacy-first document scanner for iPhone
articles.description:
Iâ€™m an indie iOS developer and I built a small tool because I couldnâ€™t find a simple, fast, privacy-respecting document scanner on the App Store.

Most scanners today require an account, upload files to their cloud, or push subscriptions aggressively. I wanted something that opens instantly, works offline, exports clean PDFs, and doesnâ€™t track anything.

So I made Scan.

It opens as fast as the Camera app, processes documents locally, and doesnâ€™t require an account. The design is inspired by the older, simpler iOS UI from the iOS 6 era because Iâ€™ve always liked how clean and fast it felt.

Iâ€™d love feedback, especially from other developers: â€“ Is the interaction flow intuitive enough? â€“ Does the â€œprivacy-first + old-school designâ€ direction make sense in 2025? â€“ Anything obviously missing for a 1.0?

Happy to answer questions.
